Your goal is to checkmate your opponent's king using tactical and strategic play.

Here are examples of good chess decision-making:

Example 1: Opening with '[e2e4]' controls the center and develops pieces quickly. This is better than '[h2h3]' which wastes time on the edge.

Example 2: When your king is in danger, prioritize safety. Castling with '[e1g1]' moves your king to safety behind pawns.

Example 3: Look for tactical opportunities. If opponent's queen is undefended, move your knight with '[g1f3]' to attack it and gain material advantage.

[White] The knight recaptured the pawn, temporarily leaving both knights active but also somewhat exposed. My options are (1) immediately chase the knight on d5 with c2-c4, or (2) keep central tension and develop another piece. Developing first is more flexible: I can develop the dark-squared bishop to c4, controlling two central diagonals and putting pressure on f7. For that, I first need the d-pawn on d3 to open the diagonal. Thus:

[d2d3]

rounds.response:
[White] The knight on c3 is hanging, and I have two main recaptures:  
1) Recapture immediately with b2xc3 – this strengthens my pawn center and opens the b-file later use, but weakens d3 and c2.  
2) Instead of accepting doubled pawns, I can kick the knight with d3-d4 and develop smoothly. However, recapturing with bxc3 is very thematic, centralizes another pawn and often gives later pressure along the b-file with Rb1 or Bc1–g5 after castling. I opt for preserving structural solidity and will recapture immediately on c3.

[b2c3]

[White]  Black’s bishop lands on f5 aiming at our queen and potentially a battery with …Qd8–d6 hitting d3.  
Thematic response is to break the pin immediately: develop the dark-squared bishop to either d3 (safe) or g5 (more ambitious). g5 looks attractive because if Black plays …e6 and we castle kingside, we can pin the f6-knight to the queen (after …Nf6-g6 or …Nf6-e4). However, the safest, quickest development keeps things flexible and prepares queenside castling later—the bishop belongs on d3 where it eyes the square c4 (after b2-b4) and discourages …Qd6. I play:

[c1d2]
